title: Why Big Tech Is Making a Big Play for Live Sports
abstract: Competing for rights to broadcast games from the N.F.L. and other leagues could be hard for broadcast and cable companies that “aren’t playing by the same financial rules.”
byline: By Tripp Mickle, Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin

multimedia.caption: Tech companies, eager to expand their streaming audiences, increasingly see live sports as a way to do it.
Tech companies, eager to expand their streaming audiences, increasingly see live sports as a way to do it.

title: Ties Between Alex Jones and Radio Network Show Economics of Misinformation
abstract: The Genesis Communications Network built a lucrative business alongside the radio host, whose show the company has syndicated for more than two decades.

title: We Need to Keep Building Houses, Even if No One Wants to Buy
abstract: Right now, builders have too many homes and not enough people to sell them to. In the long term, the United States has the opposite problem: Not enough houses for all the people who want them.
byline: By Conor Dougherty and Ben Casselman

multimedia.caption: “We’re going to look project by project and say which ones are we are going to go ahead on and which we are going to take a pause on,” said Randal Lewis of the Lewis Group of Companies, which is doing work in Chino, Calif.
multimedia.copyright: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

title: How Software Is Stifling Competition and Slowing Innovation
abstract: A tech entrepreneur turned academic takes on the “disruption myth.” Big companies, he argues, have built software moats against rivals.
des_facet: The New Goliaths: How Corporations Use Software to Dominate Industries, Kill Innovation, and Undermine Regulation (Book)

multimedia.caption: “Software isn’t accelerating creative destruction today, software is suppressing it,” James Bessen says.
multimedia.copyright: Greta Rybus for The New York Times

title: Inside Ukraine’s Thriving Tech Sector
abstract: Ukrainian technology companies have earned billions. But with most executives unable to meet foreign clients, the good times may not last.

title: Google Fires Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Conscious
abstract: The engineer, Blake Lemoine, contends that the company’s language model has a soul. The company denies that and says he violated its security policies.

multimedia.caption: Google confirmed that it had fired one of its engineers, Blake Lemoine, who had raised concerns about how the company was testing an artificial intelligence chatbot.

title: Why You Should Be Wary of Wall Street’s Upbeat Stock Forecasts
abstract: Amid rising inflation and the threat of recession, corporate earnings are coming under pressure.

title: When a Woman’s Retirement Account Becomes the Family Emergency Fund
abstract: Women break into their savings to cover all kinds of expenses: home down payments, repairs, medical bills. That can hurt them years later.

multimedia.caption: Vickie Elisa tapped her Roth individual retirement account for home repairs and to help family. “I told myself, once I had built up a pretty good cash flow, I would start building it back up again,” she said.

title: This Week in Business: Amazon’s Latest Acquisition
abstract: Netflix reports a drop in subscribers, but it could have been worse. The Fed announces its next rate increase. And we’ll hear how strong, or weak, the U.S. economy is.

title: A Novelist Says a Movie Fails to Credit Her. The Film World Shrugs.
abstract: Geling Yan says that she is owed a screen credit for the Chinese film “One Second” — and that companies bringing it to Western audiences are complicit in censoring her.

multimedia.caption: The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.

title: China Evergrande C.E.O. Resigns After Loans Come Under Scrutiny
abstract: The resignation was the latest setback for the embattled Chinese property developer, which is expected to announce a plan to restructure its debt of more than $300 billion.

title: In Japan, Abe Suspect’s Grudge Against Unification Church Is a Familiar One
abstract: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe said his mother’s huge donations to the church bankrupted his family. Many others in Japan have similar stories.
byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

multimedia.caption: Tomihiro Tanaka, president of the Japanese branch of the Unification Church, during a moment of silence for former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a Tokyo news conference last week.

title: Luxury Rental Buildings Take ‘Working From Home’ to the Next Level
abstract: Developers are adding professional office spaces to the list of amenities in their mostly new buildings in cities around the country.

title: T-Mobile Reaches $500 Million Settlement in Huge 2021 Data Breach
abstract: The company, which said the hacking had affected 76.6 million people, agreed to pay $350 million to settle claims and spend $150 million to bolster security.

multimedia.caption: T-Mobile’s proposed agreement says payments to individual claimants can’t exceed $2,500.

abstract: The company’s leader for 40 years, he was under scrutiny after a report of a $3 million settlement with an employee.

title: A ‘wild day’ in the bond market reflects rising recession fears.
abstract: Weak economic data has generated worries about slowing economic growth.
byline: By Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek

title: Herbert Diess, Volkswagen’s C.E.O., is stepping down.

title: Biden’s New Economic Scorecard: The Price at the Pump
abstract: The president has grown fond of boasting about a prolonged streak of falling gasoline prices, a move wrapped in risk and irony.

title: How to Lower Your Summer Electric Bill
abstract: Start with a seasonal tuneup of your air-conditioning system, experts say. Close shades or blinds during the day. And raise your thermostat — even by just one degree.

abstract: The internet giant acquired One Medical, a national chain of primary care clinics, for $3.9 billion.

title: Twitter’s earnings falter as it fights with Elon Musk.
abstract: The social media company swung to a loss in the second quarter and cited “uncertainty” over its pending takeover by the billionaire Tesla chief executive as a factor.
byline: By Kate Conger and Adam Satariano

multimedia.caption: Twitter again declined to hold an earnings call with Wall Street analysts, avoiding potential questions about Elon Musk’s impact on the business.

title: Bucking the global trend, Russia lowers interest rates again.
abstract: Russia’s central bank cut its interest rate to 8 percent on Friday, lower than before the invasion of Ukraine, citing “subdued” consumer demand.

title: Russia keeps Germany guessing on gas shipments.
Germany bails out Uniper, a crucial gas provider squeezed by Russia.
abstract: The government announced a multibillion-euro rescue and agreed to acquire a 30 percent stake in the company.
byline: By Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed

title: YouTube will take down ‘unsafe’ abortion how-to videos.
abstract: The video service said it would take a closer look at the abortion content on its platform.

abstract: The case is the first time criminal insider-trading charges have been filed that involve cryptocurrency assets, a U.S. attorney said.
byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany
